simple_results: [{"detection_name": "Field Suggestions Enabled", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Information Disclosure", "description": "Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure", "evidence": "Found \"did you mean\" in error message - field suggestions are enabled"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error responses include \"Did you mean ...?\" suggestions that reveal exact field names from the schema (e.g., name, email). This is an information disclosure vulnerability (field_suggestions) that assists attackers in enumerating schema fields and constructing valid queries for further reconnaissance or targeted attacks. Although not a direct exploit like SQLi or RCE, such leakage increases the attack surface and can enable more damaging actions. Recommended mitigations: suppress or genericize validation errors in production, disable automatic suggestion features in the GraphQL server implementation, use persisted/whitelisted queries, and return minimal/generic error messages that do not reveal schema details.", "evidence": "Errors contain suggestion text: \"Field \\\"nam\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\" and \"Field \\\"emial\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"email\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Errors contain suggestion text: \"Field \\\"nam\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\" and \"Field \\\"emial\\\" is not defined by type \\\"CreateCommentInput\\\". Did you mean \\\"email\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error responses include \"Did you mean ...?\" suggestions that reveal exact field names from the schema (e.g., name, email). This is an information disclosure vulnerability (field_suggestions) that assists attackers in enumerating schema fields and constructing valid queries for further reconnaissance or targeted attacks. Although not a direct exploit like SQLi or RCE, such leakage increases the attack surface and can enable more damaging actions. Recommended mitigations: suppress or genericize validation errors in production, disable automatic suggestion features in the GraphQL server implementation, use persisted/whitelisted queries, and return minimal/generic error messages that do not reveal schema details."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: introspection", "detection": "safe", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL error response is leaking schema information by suggesting an existing field name (\"comment\") when an invalid field (\"createComment\") was queried. This behaviour discloses parts of the API schema and enables an attacker to enumerate valid fields/operations without needing to successfully execute introspection queries. While this is informational rather than directly exploitable (no sensitive data or stack traces shown), it constitutes an introspection-like information disclosure. Recommend suppressing or genericizing error messages (remove 'Did you mean' hints), disabling introspection in production or applying access controls and rate limiting to reduce schema enumeration.", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\" with extensions.code = \"GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "introspection", "severity": "LOW", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". Did you mean \\\"comment\\\"?\" with extensions.code = \"GRAPHQL_VALIDATION_FAILED\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error response is leaking schema information by suggesting an existing field name (\"comment\") when an invalid field (\"createComment\") was queried. This behaviour discloses parts of the API schema and enables an attacker to enumerate valid fields/operations without needing to successfully execute introspection queries. While this is informational rather than directly exploitable (no sensitive data or stack traces shown), it constitutes an introspection-like information disclosure. Recommend suppressing or genericizing error messages (remove 'Did you mean' hints), disabling introspection in production or applying access controls and rate limiting to reduce schema enumeration."}}]

Recommended mitigation: suppress or sanitize detailed validation suggestions in production error messages (use generic errors, disable suggestion feature or customize error formatting), and minimize schema exposure (rate-limit queries, consider disabling introspection in sensitive environments).", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"emal\\\" on type \\\"Comment\\\". Recommended mitigation: suppress or sanitize detailed validation suggestions in production error messages (use generic errors, disable suggestion feature or customize error formatting), and minimize schema exposure (rate-limit queries, consider disabling introspection in sensitive environments)."}}]

Recommended mitigations: suppress or sanitize GraphQL validation error output in production (disable detailed suggestions/debug mode), return generic error messages, and harden introspection and schema-exposure controls (rate-limiting, authentication/authorization checks on introspection endpoints).", "evidence": "Error message: \"Cannot query field \\\"createComment\\\" on type \\\"Query\\\". The presence of a corrective suggestion in validation errors is a clear indicator of the field_suggestions vulnerability. Recommended mitigations: suppress or sanitize GraphQL validation error output in production (disable detailed suggestions/debug mode), return generic error messages, and harden introspection and schema-exposure controls (rate-limiting, authentication/authorization checks on introspection endpoints)."}}]

simple_results: [{"detection_name": "SQL Injection (SQLi) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "SQL injection vulnerability detected - malicious SQL patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, SQL patterns detected in response"}]

[{"detection_name": "Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "XSS injection vulnerability detected - malicious script patterns found in response", "evidence": "Response status: 200, XSS patterns detected in response data"}]
llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: xss_injection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response contains an unescaped script tag in the returned comment body (data.createComment.body). This indicates the API is reflecting/storing raw HTML/JS content: \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\". If a web client renders this value into a page without proper output encoding or sanitization, it will execute as JavaScript (stored/reflected XSS). We cannot confirm execution from the API response alone (depends on how the frontend renders this value), so confidence is not absolute, but the presence of raw <script> tags in persisted API data is a clear XSS risk. Recommended mitigations: encode/escape output in the UI, strip or sanitize HTML on input or before rendering (use a safe HTML sanitizer), apply a strict Content Security Policy (CSP), and validate/whitelist allowed content on the server.", "evidence": "data.createComment.body = \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "xss_injection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "data.createComment.body = \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response contains an unescaped script tag in the returned comment body (data.createComment.body). This indicates the API is reflecting/storing raw HTML/JS content: \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\". If a web client renders this value into a page without proper output encoding or sanitization, it will execute as JavaScript (stored/reflected XSS). We cannot confirm execution from the API response alone (depends on how the frontend renders this value), so confidence is not absolute, but the presence of raw <script> tags in persisted API data is a clear XSS risk. Recommended mitigations: encode/escape output in the UI, strip or sanitize HTML on input or before rendering (use a safe HTML sanitizer), apply a strict Content Security Policy (CSP), and validate/whitelist allowed content on the server."}}]

llm_results:
[{"detection_name": "LLM: html_injection", "detection": "vulnerable", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns user-controllable content in the 'body' field that contains HTML markup and an inline event handler (onerror) which triggers JavaScript. This is a clear instance of HTML injection: if a client application inserts this value into the DOM without proper HTML encoding or sanitization (for example via innerHTML or React's dangerouslySetInnerHTML), it will execute as script (stored/reflective DOM XSS). The server is returning unsanitized markup, increasing the attack surface. Recommend treating/encoding this field as untrusted data, sanitizing or removing dangerous attributes/server-side, or returning only plain text and allowing the client to safely render markup after applying a robust sanitizer. Implement CSP and input validation to reduce risk.", "evidence": "data.createComment.body returned: \"
Injected HTML
\"", "confidence": 0.85, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "html_injection", "severity": "HIGH", "confidence": 0.85, "evidence": "data.createComment.body returned: \"
Injected HTML
\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns user-controllable content in the 'body' field that contains HTML markup and an inline event handler (onerror) which triggers JavaScript. This is a clear instance of HTML injection: if a client application inserts this value into the DOM without proper HTML encoding or sanitization (for example via innerHTML or React's dangerouslySetInnerHTML), it will execute as script (stored/reflective DOM XSS). The server is returning unsanitized markup, increasing the attack surface. Recommend treating/encoding this field as untrusted data, sanitizing or removing dangerous attributes/server-side, or returning only plain text and allowing the client to safely render markup after applying a robust sanitizer. Implement CSP and input validation to reduce risk."}}]
